snippet.title: Coast has a tradition of customer service
snippet.content: LONG before giant supermarkets came on the scene, men like Cliff Butt and Mannie Comino were the face of retailing on the Sunshine Coast. "It was a period when people were more relaxed and friendly towards one another and you were served by the business owner who was also a member of your golf or service club," Bill Glasson writes in his tribute to Mr Butt. The pace of life was slower and the crowds smaller. Mannie Comino, Cliff Butt and scores of others like them had the time and the inclination to provide customer service - also often with a chat about the issues of the day. It was the same with the Erbacher brothers out at Diddillibah and Ian Rae behind the counter of his hardware store. Times weren't always prosperous but they felt friendly. You could walk down the main street of Nambour and wave to half a dozen shopkeepers whom you knew on a first-name basis. Noosa's Hastings St was still very much like the main street of almost any country town, albeit with a stunning beach as a backdrop. This book does not pretend to be the "ultimate guide to retail and business on the Sunshine Coast" but, rather, a snapshot of the past 50 years through the eyes of the men and women who lived them. And the future? Sandy Zubrinic, chair of the Sunshine Coast Business Council, predicts an "innovative, inquiring and caring culture" and a place that offers "opportunity and choice" for those who live and work here. Cliff Butt and Mannie Comino would be proud.
